summary: syncytial virus (RSV) is the most common pathogen causing lower respiratory tract infections (LRTIs) in 2014, human coronavirus (HCoV) caused not only upper respiratory infections but also LRTIs more commonly than in other years. researchers have become more interested in human coronaviruses (HCoV) in the Republic of Korea, a single HCoV infection was detected every month in 2013, except June through September, in Seoul. from 2010 to 2012, HCoV-OC43 was the most prevalent subtype. in 2014, HCoV positive rates were lower than in other years. all clinical data were collected by retrospective review of an electric medical record system. we defined LRTIs as pneumonia or bronchiolitis. when a patient had abnormal lung sounds, such as rales or crackles, with local infiltration or consolidation on chest X-ray. the peak incidence of HCoV in our hospital during the study period was during the 48th week of 2014. a certain amount of lag time between increases in nationwide HCoV infections and our hospital’s pediatric LRTIs due to HCoV. the most frequent co-infection virus with HCoV was RSV. one patient with HCoV-CO43 and HCoV-NL63 infection, one with HCo-OC43, and rhinovirus was detected. most of them had a lower respiratory tract infection, such as pneumonia, bronchiolitis, or bronchitis. a nebulizer was less commonly used in the CoV only-infected group. a nebulizer was less commonly used in the co-infected group. n (%) Antibiotic use 19 (86.4) 17 (100) 7 (100) 2 (100) Nebulizer use 14 (63.6) 17 (100) 7 (100) 2 (100) Steroid use 4 (18.2) 11 (64.7) 1 (14.3) 1 (50) HCoV, human coronavirus, respiratory syncytial virus; PIV, parainfluenza virus.
